## The context

## About the Authors

To get to know these authors a little bit, see the table below containing some information about some of these authors and books.

```{r, echo = FALSE}

library(tidyverse) # Tibbles
library(DT) # Interactive table


name <- c("André Aciman", "Tomasz Jedrowski", "Madeline Miller", "Hanya Yanagihara", "Adam Silvera") # Construct name variable
gender <- c("Man", "Man", "Woman", "Woman", "Man") # Construct gender variable
age <- as.numeric(c(74, 40, 47, 51, 35)) # Construct numerical age variable
book <- c("Call me by your name", "Swimming in the dark", "A song for Achilles", "A little life", "They both die at the end")

audat <- as_tibble(cbind(name, gender, age, book)) # Bind variables into a single tibble

autab <- audat |> 
  datatable(options = list(pageLength = 5)) # Create a interactive table

```

```{r, label="autab-display", cache=TRUE, echo=TRUE}

autab   # Display the result

```

## Let me introduce you to the main character

These are Oscar (l) and Lloyd (r). They are both statisticians.

![](ol.png){fig-align="center" width="60%"}

## The favorite equation of Oscar and Lloyd

Love may be unpredictable, but their distribution is normal.

$$
\begin{aligned}
X &\sim \mathcal{N}(\mu, \sigma^2) \\
f(x) &= \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi\sigma^2}}
       \exp\!\left(
       -\frac{(x - \mu)^2}{2\sigma^2}
       \right) \\
&\quad \text{with } \mu = \text{“Oscar”}, \;
      \sigma^2 = \text{“Lloyd”}
\end{aligned}
$$
